Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc').     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201cphoton storage\u201d and \u201canti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT)\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network target:\n  1. A two\u2010hop quantum\u2010repeater teleportation where each Bell\u2010measurement node is implemented by an APT\u2010symmetric four\u2010port interferometer, and the entangled\u2010pair photons are held in passive delay lines (\u201cstorage\u201d) until the measurement fires.\n  2. A cascaded entanglement\u2010swapping of three qudit pairs (d\u22653), where the two swapping stations are APT\u2010symmetric multiports, and inter\u2010swap photons are buffered in fiber\u2010loop delays.\n  3. A linear\u2010optical simulation of a discrete\u2010time non\u2010Hermitian quantum walk (APT symmetric) in a multiport network, with a loop acting as photon memory so that the walker photon revisits the same interferometer N times.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus\u2010obstacles:\n  1. Two\u2010hop teleportation with APT\u2010symmetric Bell measurements: \n       \u2022 Novel: multi\u2010hop teleportation using non\u2010Hermitian symmetric measurement modules.  \n       \u2022 Pytheus\u2010obstacles: need to encode memory delays abstractly (use removed_connections to forbid direct source\u2192detector edges); specify a heralded mapping rather than fixed state generation.\n  2. Cascaded qudit\u2010swapping with APT ports:  \n       \u2022 Overlaps with existing high\u2010d entanglement\u2010swapping experiments but adds APT symmetry.  \n       \u2022 Pytheus can handle qudits but we risk repetition of #3 and #4 in the explored list.\n  3. Discrete\u2010time APT quantum walk with loop storage:\n       \u2022 Quite speculative; Pytheus cannot currently optimize loops/time\u2010evolution directly\u2014too far from its domain.\n\nStep 3: Pick the teleportation\u2010repeater idea.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it merges multi\u2010hop quantum teleportation (a small network) with non\u2010Hermitian (APT symmetric) linear\u2010optical measurement modules, a concept not yet explored in quantum\u2010network experiments. It also leverages passive photon\u2010storage delays purely through static connectivity constraints, avoiding active feedback.\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n     \u2022 Pytheus can optimize linear\u2010optical Bell\u2010measurement modules with ancilla photons and post\u2010selection (\u201cnum_anc\u201d & \u201cheralding_out\u201d).  \n     \u2022 We encode \u201cphoton storage\u201d via removed_connections that forbid any single\u2010source path directly linking asynchronous modes\u2014effectively modeling passive delays.  \n     \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed, only beamsplitters, phase shifters, sources, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n     \u2022 The target is a heralded input\u2010to\u2010output state mapping (teleportation) rather than mere state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nWe design a two\u2010hop photonic teleportation network (a minimal repeater) where Nodes A\u2192B and B\u2192C each share one Bell pair from probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources. Node A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0. Source 1 creates an entangled pair in modes 1 (to B) & 2 (to A), Source 2 creates a second pair in modes 3 (to B) & 4 (to C).  \n\nNode B implements two sequential Bell\u2010measurements:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2081 between the unknown (mode 0) and the local half (mode 2) of the first pair.\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2082 between the teleported photon emerging from M\u2081 (mode 1\u2032) and the local half (mode 3) of the second pair.\n\nEach Bell\u2010measurement M\u1d62 is realized by a 4-port linear\u2010optical network whose scattering matrix is constrained to satisfy anti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT) symmetry (i.e. S = \u2013P S* P). Each M\u1d62 uses two additional ancilla photons (modes a\u1d62,b\u1d62) and two heralding detectors (d\u1d62,e\u1d62). Successful coincident clicks at {d\u1d62,e\u1d62} herald the Bell outcome. Upon double heralding (M\u2081 and M\u2082 succeed), the unknown state |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0 is faithfully transferred to mode 4 at Node C.\n\nPhoton storage is implemented passively by encoding connectivity constraints: the two pair sources emit asynchronously and we forbid any direct source\u2192detector paths that would mix modes 1\u21c42 (for M\u2081) or 1\u2032\u21c43 (for M\u2082) before the other photon arrives. Practically, in the Pytheus config we use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to block paths from a given source to certain detectors, enforcing that photons must traverse the APT module and effectively \u201cwait\u201d for their partners.\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n  \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010measurements are a new primitive in linear\u2010optics networks\u2014non\u2010Hermitian symmetry in the measurement module could yield unexpected interference or loss\u2010robustness features.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded teleportation demonstrates a minimal repeater architecture within a single static linear\u2010optical network, illustrating network\u2010level functionality beyond state generation.  \n  \u2022 The passive\u2010storage abstraction via connectivity constraints is a general trick: it can be scaled to longer repeater chains or multiple hops.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus parameters (sketch):\n  num_pre: 1  \n  edges_tried: 50  \n  num_anc: 4  (two ancillas per Bell module)  \n  single_emitters: []  \n  removed_connections: [\n    # block direct creation of both photons in M\u2081 by same source\n    [source1, detector_for_mode0], [source1, detector_for_mode2], \n    # block direct creation for M\u2082 similarly\n    [source2, detector_for_mode1\u2032], [source2, detector_for_mode3]\n  ]  \n  heralding_out: [[d1,e1],[d2,e2]]  \n  target_mapping: input modes [0,1,3] \u2192 output mode [4], conditional on heralding, reproducing the input qubit.\n\nThis proposal is ready for Pytheus to optimize the two APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules and demonstrate networked teleportation with built-in passive storage."
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nWe design a two\u2010hop photonic teleportation network (a minimal repeater) where Nodes A\u2192B and B\u2192C each share one Bell pair from probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources. Node A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0. Source 1 creates an entangled pair in modes 1 (to B) & 2 (to A), Source 2 creates a second pair in modes 3 (to B) & 4 (to C).  \n\nNode B implements two sequential Bell\u2010measurements:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2081 between the unknown (mode 0) and the local half (mode 2) of the first pair.\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2082 between the teleported photon emerging from M\u2081 (mode 1\u2032) and the local half (mode 3) of the second pair.\n\nEach Bell\u2010measurement M\u1d62 is realized by a 4-port linear\u2010optical network whose scattering matrix is constrained to satisfy anti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT) symmetry (i.e. S = \u2013P S* P). Each M\u1d62 uses two additional ancilla photons (modes a\u1d62,b\u1d62) and two heralding detectors (d\u1d62,e\u1d62). Successful coincident clicks at {d\u1d62,e\u1d62} herald the Bell outcome. Upon double heralding (M\u2081 and M\u2082 succeed), the unknown state |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0 is faithfully transferred to mode 4 at Node C.\n\nPhoton storage is implemented passively by encoding connectivity constraints: the two pair sources emit asynchronously and we forbid any direct source\u2192detector paths that would mix modes 1\u21c42 (for M\u2081) or 1\u2032\u21c43 (for M\u2082) before the other photon arrives. Practically, in the Pytheus config we use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to block paths from a given source to certain detectors, enforcing that photons must traverse the APT module and effectively \u201cwait\u201d for their partners.\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n  \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010measurements are a new primitive in linear\u2010optics networks\u2014non\u2010Hermitian symmetry in the measurement module could yield unexpected interference or loss\u2010robustness features.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded teleportation demonstrates a minimal repeater architecture within a single static linear\u2010optical network, illustrating network\u2010level functionality beyond state generation.  \n  \u2022 The passive\u2010storage abstraction via connectivity constraints is a general trick: it can be scaled to longer repeater chains or multiple hops.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus parameters (sketch):\n  num_pre: 1  \n  edges_tried: 50  \n  num_anc: 4  (two ancillas per Bell module)  \n  single_emitters: []  \n  removed_connections: [\n    # block direct creation of both photons in M\u2081 by same source\n    [source1, detector_for_mode0], [source1, detector_for_mode2], \n    # block direct creation for M\u2082 similarly\n    [source2, detector_for_mode1\u2032], [source2, detector_for_mode3]\n  ]  \n  heralding_out: [[d1,e1],[d2,e2]]  \n  target_mapping: input modes [0,1,3] \u2192 output mode [4], conditional on heralding, reproducing the input qubit.\n\nThis proposal is ready for Pytheus to optimize the two APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules and demonstrate networked teleportation with built-in passive storage.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The core novelty claimed\u2014the use of APT\u2010symmetric (non\u2010Hermitian) Bell modules in a two\u2010hop teleportation chain\u2014is highly reminiscent of the earlier \u201cPT\u2010Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non\u2010Hermitian Bell\u2010State Projection\u201d from the ensemble. Aside from swapping PT \u2192 APT, it is effectively the same new measurement primitive. Cascading two Bell measurements to build a minimal repeater is also just the textbook entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation repeater concept in static form\u2014no genuine new network protocol or state space is opened up. In its present form this remains an incremental extension of known PT\u2010Bell analyzers plus simple cascade. It does not yet rise above the bar for a truly novel PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal\u2019s APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules are essentially the same non\u2010Hermitian/ PT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers already suggested, and chaining two teleportations is a standard repeater trick. To improve, you\u2019d need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014e.g. a multi\u2010hop protocol with adaptive feed-forward or error\u2010correction using the non\u2010Hermitian modules in a way that cannot be reduced to back-to-back teleportation with delay lines\u2014and demonstrate that the APT symmetry offers a clear advantage (loss robustness, success probability improvement, novel interference effect) provably beyond existing PT\u2010symmetric schemes."
}

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Therefore the corresponding value is [0, 1] as the photons 0 and 1 (making up the final 3d Bell state) should have no common source\\n\\nThe ancillary particles are measured by a third party, similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits).\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two particles with dimensionality four.', 'foldername': '4d-ES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 20, 'ftol': 1e-05, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22', '33'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.2, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 1]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': True, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"photon storage\" and \"anti parity time\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A two\u2010hop quantum\u2010repeater teleportation where each Bell\u2010measurement node is implemented by an APT\u2010symmetric four\u2010port interferometer, and the entangled\u2010pair photons are held in passive delay lines (\u201cstorage\u201d) until the measurement fires.\n  2. A linear\u2010optical simulation of a discrete\u2010time non\u2010Hermitian quantum walk (APT symmetric) in a multiport network, with a loop acting as photon memory so that the walker photon revisits the same interferometer N times.\n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus\u2010obstacles:\n  1. Cascaded qudit\u2010swapping with APT ports:  \n       \u2022 Overlaps with existing high\u2010d entanglement\u2010swapping experiments but adds APT symmetry.  \n       \u2022 Pytheus can handle qudits but we risk repetition of #3 and #4 in the explored list.\n  3. Discrete\u2010time APT quantum walk with loop storage:\n       \u2022 Quite speculative; Pytheus cannot currently optimize loops/time\u2010evolution directly\u2014too far from its domain.\n\nStep 3: Pick the teleportation\u2010repeater idea.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it merges multi\u2010hop quantum teleportation (a small network) with non\u2010Hermitian (APT symmetric) linear\u2010optical measurement modules, a concept not yet explored in quantum\u2010network experiments. It also leverages passive photon\u2010storage delays purely through static connectivity constraints, avoiding active feedback.\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework because:\n     \u2022 Pytheus can optimize linear\u2010optical Bell\u2010measurement modules with ancilla photons and post\u2010selection (\u201cnum_anc\u201d & \u201cheralding_out\u201d).  \n     \u2022 We encode \u201cphoton storage\u201d via removed_connections that forbid any single\u2010source path directly linking asynchronous modes\u2014effectively modeling passive delays.  \n     \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities are needed, only beamsplitters, phase shifters, sources, and number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n     \u2022 The target is a heralded input\u2010to\u2010output state mapping (teleportation) rather than mere state generation.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is a proposal for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nWe design a two\u2010hop photonic teleportation network (a minimal repeater) where Nodes A\u2192B and B\u2192C each share one Bell pair from probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources. Node A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0. Source 1 creates an entangled pair in modes 1 (to B) & 2 (to A), Source 2 creates a second pair in modes 3 (to B) & 4 (to C).  \n\nNode B implements two sequential Bell\u2010measurements:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2081 between the unknown (mode 0) and the local half (mode 2) of the first pair.\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2082 between the teleported photon emerging from M\u2081 (mode 1\u2032) and the local half (mode 3) of the second pair.\n\nEach Bell\u2010measurement M\u1d62 is realized by a 4-port linear\u2010optical network whose scattering matrix is constrained to satisfy anti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT) symmetry (i.e. S = \u2013P S* P). Each M\u1d62 uses two additional ancilla photons (modes a\u1d62,b\u1d62) and two heralding detectors (d\u1d62,e\u1d62). Successful coincident clicks at {d\u1d62,e\u1d62} herald the Bell outcome. Upon double heralding (M\u2081 and M\u2082 succeed), the unknown state |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0 is faithfully transferred to mode 4 at Node C.\n\nPhoton storage is implemented passively by encoding connectivity constraints: the two pair sources emit asynchronously and we forbid any direct source\u2192detector paths that would mix modes 1\u21c42 (for M\u2081) or 1\u2032\u21c43 (for M\u2082) before the other photon arrives. Practically, in the Pytheus config we use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to block paths from a given source to certain detectors, enforcing that photons must traverse the APT module and effectively \u201cwait\u201d for their partners.\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n  \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010measurements are a new primitive in linear\u2010optics networks\u2014non\u2010Hermitian symmetry in the measurement module could yield unexpected interference or loss\u2010robustness features.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded teleportation demonstrates a minimal repeater architecture within a single static linear\u2010optical network, illustrating network\u2010level functionality beyond state generation.  \n  \u2022 The passive\u2010storage abstraction via connectivity constraints is a general trick: it can be scaled to longer repeater chains or multiple hops.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus parameters (sketch):\n  num_pre: 1  \n  edges_tried: 50  \n  num_anc: 4  (two ancillas per Bell module)  \n  single_emitters: []  \n  removed_connections: [\n    # block direct creation of both photons in M\u2081 by same source\n    [source1, detector_for_mode0], [source1, detector_for_mode2], \n    # block direct creation for M\u2082 similarly\n    [source2, detector_for_mode1\u2032], [source2, detector_for_mode3]\n  ]  \n  heralding_out: [[d1,e1],[d2,e2]]  \n  target_mapping: input modes [0,1,3] \u2192 output mode [4], conditional on heralding, reproducing the input qubit.\n\nThis proposal is ready for Pytheus to optimize the two APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules and demonstrate networked teleportation with built-in passive storage.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal\u2019s APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules are essentially the same non\u2010Hermitian/ PT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers already suggested, and chaining two teleportations is a standard repeater trick. To improve, you\u2019d need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014e.g. a multi\u2010hop protocol with adaptive feed-forward or error\u2010correction using the non\u2010Hermitian modules in a way that cannot be reduced to back-to-back teleportation with delay lines\u2014and demonstrate that the APT symmetry offers a clear advantage (loss robustness, success probability improvement, novel interference effect) provably beyond existing PT\u2010symmetric schemes.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to merge \u201cphoton storage\u201d and \u201canti\u2010parity\u2010time\u201d (APT) in a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network protocol (no state\u2010generation targets):\n  1. A ring of three measurement\u2010induced teleportations that cyclically permutes three qubits (A\u2192B\u2192C\u2192A), with each Bell\u2010analyzer realized by an APT\u2010symmetric linear\u2010optical module and all \u201cwaiting\u201d photons buffered by passive\u2010storage delays encoded via removed_connections.\n  2. A two\u2010hop entanglement\u2010swapping repeater where the central node uses an APT\u2010symmetric multiport to fuse two Bell pairs sequentially, storing photons in fiber\u2010loop delays until both swaps succeed.\n  3. A measurement\u2010based discrete\u2010time quantum walk on a triangle graph governed by APT\u2010symmetric scattering, where one photon revisits the same APT module several times via passive loops (modelled by forbidden direct paths).\n\nStep 2: Check novelty & Pytheus\u2010suitability:\n  1. The cyclic teleportation network is novel\u2014no prior back\u2010to\u2010back swap network permutes three unknown qubits in a loop using APT symmetry. It is purely measurement\u2010based, uses only linear optics, probabilistic sources, ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors, and encodes storage via connectivity constraints.\n  2. The two\u2010hop repeater is too close to standard cascaded teleportation\u2014they already exist in Pytheus examples.\n  3. The discrete\u2010time APT walk with loops is too far from Pytheus\u2019s static\u2010linear\u2010optics domain (requires explicit loops/time\u2010steps).\n\nStep 3: Pick idea #1: cyclic APT\u2010symmetric teleportation ring.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it implements a three\u2010party cyclic permutation of unknown qubits in a single static linear\u2010optics network, using three non\u2010Hermitian (APT\u2010symmetric) Bell\u2010measurement modules. Such a measurement\u2010induced cyclic SWAP has not been explored\u2014and the use of APT symmetry may introduce non\u2010reciprocal success probabilities or loss\u2010robustness around the loop.\n\nStep 5: This is feasible in the Pytheus framework and meets all constraints:\n  \u2022 Only linear optics, probabilistic pair sources, ancilla photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors are needed.  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback or cavities\u2014photon \u201cstorage\u201d is encoded as forbidden direct edges (removed_connections) so that the partner of each Bell measurement must await the other photon.  \n  \u2022 The target is a heralded mapping (cyclic permutation of three input modes into three output modes), not mere state generation.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus\u2010ready proposal:\n\nExplanation:\nWe build a three\u2010node cyclic teleportation network. Nodes A, B, C each hold an unknown qubit in modes 0,1,2 respectively. Three independent probabilistic pair\u2010sources pre\u2010share Bell pairs around the triangle:\n \u2022 S_AB emits into modes [3\u2192B] & [4\u2192A]  \n \u2022 S_BC emits into modes [5\u2192C] & [6\u2192B]  \n \u2022 S_CA emits into modes [7\u2192A] & [8\u2192C]  \n\nWe perform three Bell\u2010measurements (all implemented by four\u2010port APT\u2010symmetric linear\u2010optical analyzers):\n 1. At A: measure modes [2 (C\u2019s input) & 7 (from S_CA)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_C to mode 4 (A\u2019s output).  \n 2. At B: measure [0 (A\u2019s input) & 3 (from S_AB)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_A to mode 6 (B\u2019s output).  \n 3. At C: measure [1 (B\u2019s input) & 5 (from S_BC)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_B to mode 8 (C\u2019s output).  \n\nEach Bell module uses two ancilla photons and two heralding detectors. Passive \u201cphoton storage\u201d is enforced by removed_connections that forbid any pair\u2010source from sending both of its photons directly to a given Bell\u2010detector pair\u2014ensuring one photon must wait for its partner to traverse the APT module. Only upon triple heralding do modes [4,6,8] contain the cyclicly permuted qubits (\u03c8_C,\u03c8_A,\u03c8_B).\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 It realizes a measurement\u2010induced three\u2010party cyclic SWAP\u2014an elementary network primitive beyond single\u2010link teleportation or swapping.  \n \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric modules could exhibit directional success\u2010probability bias or loss tolerance, revealing new non\u2010Hermitian network effects.  \n \u2022 The passive\u2010storage\u2010via\u2010connectivity trick is general and scales to longer loops or higher\u2010party permutation networks.\n\nSketch of Pytheus config:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Three\u2010party cyclic teleportation with APT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers and passive storage\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_TP_APT\",\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 6,                    # two ancilla photons per Bell module\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"heralding_out\": [[dA1,dA2],[dB1,dB2],[dC1,dC2]],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    # For S_CA (modes 7\u22128) at A: forbid direct 7\u2192detectors for mode2 & one ancilla\n    [source_CA, det2], [source_CA, ancA1],\n    # For S_AB (modes 3\u22124) at B:\n    [source_AB, det0], [source_AB, ancB1],\n    # For S_BC (modes 5\u22126) at C:\n    [source_BC, det1], [source_BC, ancC1]\n  ],\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n     \"inputs\": [0,1,2],\n     \"outputs\": [4,6,8],\n     \"type\": \"conditional_permutation\"\n  }\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to optimize three APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010analyzers, demonstrating a new cyclic network primitive with photon storage and non\u2010Hermitian symmetry."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. Using three probabilistic EPR sources, linear-optics routing into two Bell-measurement stations, and post-selection on the control measurement, this experiment realizes the target entanglement-switch quantum switch primitive without state-generation or dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Coherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a generalized three-photon entanglement-swapping protocol\u2014targeting \u201cCoherence-Assisted Entanglement Swapping under Amplitude Damping\u201d\u2014in which two probabilistic Bell-pair sources and an auxiliary single-photon coherence qubit each traverse independent amplitude-damping channels. A three-mode linear-optics interferometer with photon-number-resolving heralding converts the residual local coherence into nonlocal entanglement between distant output photons A and D, outperforming conventional two-link swapping in the presence of loss.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. By heralding the projector onto the PT-modified Bell state (the target map) and tuning its gain/loss parameter \u03b3, the protocol controllably generates a two-photon output |\u03a8_AD\u27e9\u221d|HH\u27e9+\u03b3\u2009e^{i\u03d5}|VV\u27e9 with adjustable, non-maximal entanglement.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. By measuring the teleportation fidelity of the explicit Bell-state target |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between A and C as a function of the amplitude ratio J\u2082/J\u2081, we directly reproduce the ground-state crossover and frustration physics of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 model.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Noisy Entanglement Swapping with Coherent Quantum Noise Cancellation  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose an entanglement-swapping experiment in which two independent noisy links are modelled by ancilla photon-pair sources and, at the central station, a standard Bell-state projection on the signal modes is combined with Mach\u2013Zehnder interference on the noise modes to enact coherent cancellation of correlated mechanical-like noise. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a proposal for Pytheus:\n\nDescription:\nWe design a two\u2010hop photonic teleportation network (a minimal repeater) where Nodes A\u2192B and B\u2192C each share one Bell pair from probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources. Node A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0. Source 1 creates an entangled pair in modes 1 (to B) & 2 (to A), Source 2 creates a second pair in modes 3 (to B) & 4 (to C).  \n\nNode B implements two sequential Bell\u2010measurements:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2081 between the unknown (mode 0) and the local half (mode 2) of the first pair.\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2082 between the teleported photon emerging from M\u2081 (mode 1\u2032) and the local half (mode 3) of the second pair.\n\nEach Bell\u2010measurement M\u1d62 is realized by a 4-port linear\u2010optical network whose scattering matrix is constrained to satisfy anti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT) symmetry (i.e. S = \u2013P S* P). Each M\u1d62 uses two additional ancilla photons (modes a\u1d62,b\u1d62) and two heralding detectors (d\u1d62,e\u1d62). Successful coincident clicks at {d\u1d62,e\u1d62} herald the Bell outcome. Upon double heralding (M\u2081 and M\u2082 succeed), the unknown state |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0 is faithfully transferred to mode 4 at Node C.\n\nPhoton storage is implemented passively by encoding connectivity constraints: the two pair sources emit asynchronously and we forbid any direct source\u2192detector paths that would mix modes 1\u21c42 (for M\u2081) or 1\u2032\u21c43 (for M\u2082) before the other photon arrives. Practically, in the Pytheus config we use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to block paths from a given source to certain detectors, enforcing that photons must traverse the APT module and effectively \u201cwait\u201d for their partners.\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n  \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010measurements are a new primitive in linear\u2010optics networks\u2014non\u2010Hermitian symmetry in the measurement module could yield unexpected interference or loss\u2010robustness features.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded teleportation demonstrates a minimal repeater architecture within a single static linear\u2010optical network, illustrating network\u2010level functionality beyond state generation.  \n  \u2022 The passive\u2010storage abstraction via connectivity constraints is a general trick: it can be scaled to longer repeater chains or multiple hops.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus parameters (sketch):\n  num_pre: 1  \n  edges_tried: 50  \n  num_anc: 4  (two ancillas per Bell module)  \n  single_emitters: []  \n  removed_connections: [\n    # block direct creation of both photons in M\u2081 by same source\n    [source1, detector_for_mode0], [source1, detector_for_mode2], \n    # block direct creation for M\u2082 similarly\n    [source2, detector_for_mode1\u2032], [source2, detector_for_mode3]\n  ]  \n  heralding_out: [[d1,e1],[d2,e2]]  \n  target_mapping: input modes [0,1,3] \u2192 output mode [4], conditional on heralding, reproducing the input qubit.\n\nThis proposal is ready for Pytheus to optimize the two APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules and demonstrate networked teleportation with built-in passive storage.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The core novelty claimed\u2014the use of APT\u2010symmetric (non\u2010Hermitian) Bell modules in a two\u2010hop teleportation chain\u2014is highly reminiscent of the earlier \u201cPT\u2010Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non\u2010Hermitian Bell\u2010State Projection\u201d from the ensemble. Aside from swapping PT \u2192 APT, it is effectively the same new measurement primitive. Cascading two Bell measurements to build a minimal repeater is also just the textbook entanglement\u2010swapping/teleportation repeater concept in static form\u2014no genuine new network protocol or state space is opened up. In its present form this remains an incremental extension of known PT\u2010Bell analyzers plus simple cascade. It does not yet rise above the bar for a truly novel PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposal\u2019s APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules are essentially the same non\u2010Hermitian/ PT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers already suggested, and chaining two teleportations is a standard repeater trick. To improve, you\u2019d need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014e.g. a multi\u2010hop protocol with adaptive feed-forward or error\u2010correction using the non\u2010Hermitian modules in a way that cannot be reduced to back-to-back teleportation with delay lines\u2014and demonstrate that the APT symmetry offers a clear advantage (loss robustness, success probability improvement, novel interference effect) provably beyond existing PT\u2010symmetric schemes.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus\u2010ready proposal:\n\nExplanation:\nWe build a three\u2010node cyclic teleportation network. Nodes A, B, C each hold an unknown qubit in modes 0,1,2 respectively. Three independent probabilistic pair\u2010sources pre\u2010share Bell pairs around the triangle:\n \u2022 S_AB emits into modes [3\u2192B] & [4\u2192A]  \n \u2022 S_BC emits into modes [5\u2192C] & [6\u2192B]  \n \u2022 S_CA emits into modes [7\u2192A] & [8\u2192C]  \n\nWe perform three Bell\u2010measurements (all implemented by four\u2010port APT\u2010symmetric linear\u2010optical analyzers):\n 1. At A: measure modes [2 (C\u2019s input) & 7 (from S_CA)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_C to mode 4 (A\u2019s output).  \n 2. At B: measure [0 (A\u2019s input) & 3 (from S_AB)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_A to mode 6 (B\u2019s output).  \n 3. At C: measure [1 (B\u2019s input) & 5 (from S_BC)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_B to mode 8 (C\u2019s output).  \n\nEach Bell module uses two ancilla photons and two heralding detectors. Passive \u201cphoton storage\u201d is enforced by removed_connections that forbid any pair\u2010source from sending both of its photons directly to a given Bell\u2010detector pair\u2014ensuring one photon must wait for its partner to traverse the APT module. Only upon triple heralding do modes [4,6,8] contain the cyclicly permuted qubits (\u03c8_C,\u03c8_A,\u03c8_B).\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 It realizes a measurement\u2010induced three\u2010party cyclic SWAP\u2014an elementary network primitive beyond single\u2010link teleportation or swapping.  \n \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric modules could exhibit directional success\u2010probability bias or loss tolerance, revealing new non\u2010Hermitian network effects.  \n \u2022 The passive\u2010storage\u2010via\u2010connectivity trick is general and scales to longer loops or higher\u2010party permutation networks.\n\nSketch of Pytheus config:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Three\u2010party cyclic teleportation with APT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers and passive storage\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_TP_APT\",\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 6,                    # two ancilla photons per Bell module\n  \"samples\": 10,\n  \"heralding_out\": [[dA1,dA2],[dB1,dB2],[dC1,dC2]],\n  \"removed_connections\": [\n    # For S_CA (modes 7\u22128) at A: forbid direct 7\u2192detectors for mode2 & one ancilla\n    [source_CA, det2], [source_CA, ancA1],\n    # For S_AB (modes 3\u22124) at B:\n    [source_AB, det0], [source_AB, ancB1],\n    # For S_BC (modes 5\u22126) at C:\n    [source_BC, det1], [source_BC, ancC1]\n  ],\n  \"target_mapping\": {\n     \"inputs\": [0,1,2],\n     \"outputs\": [4,6,8],\n     \"type\": \"conditional_permutation\"\n  }\n}\n\nThis target invites Pytheus to optimize three APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010analyzers, demonstrating a new cyclic network primitive with photon storage and non\u2010Hermitian symmetry.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The core of this proposal is simply chaining three APT\u2010symmetric Bell measurements to effect a cyclic one\u2010step teleportation of three qubits (a 3\u2010cycle permutation). While elegant as a network toy, it is just the two\u2010hop repeater idea taken around in a loop plus exactly the same APT/ non-Hermitian Bell modules you already proposed. There is no adaptive feed-forward, no multipartite entanglement resource beyond back-to-back Bell pairs, and no novel non-Hermitian interference emergent only in the cyclic geometry. This falls short of a truly new network primitive\u2014it's a straightforward generalization of standard teleportation swapping and PT-symmetric analyzers, so it isn\u2019t sufficiently novel for PRL.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL level, you need a genuinely new functional primitive (e.g. non-Hermitian modules that generate or exploit true multi-photon interference across the cycle in a non-trivial way, adaptive logic that cannot be reduced to sequential Bell measurements, or a novel multi-party entangled target state/protocol beyond a mere permutation of inputs)."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. Node A holds an unknown qubit |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0. Source 1 creates an entangled pair in modes 1 (to B) & 2 (to A), Source 2 creates a second pair in modes 3 (to B) & 4 (to C).  \n\nNode B implements two sequential Bell\u2010measurements:\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2081 between the unknown (mode 0) and the local half (mode 2) of the first pair.\n  \u2022 Bell\u2010measurement M\u2082 between the teleported photon emerging from M\u2081 (mode 1\u2032) and the local half (mode 3) of the second pair.\n\nEach Bell\u2010measurement M\u1d62 is realized by a 4-port linear\u2010optical network whose scattering matrix is constrained to satisfy anti\u2010parity\u2010time (APT) symmetry (i.e. S = \u2013P S* P). Each M\u1d62 uses two additional ancilla photons (modes a\u1d62,b\u1d62) and two heralding detectors (d\u1d62,e\u1d62). Successful coincident clicks at {d\u1d62,e\u1d62} herald the Bell outcome. Upon double heralding (M\u2081 and M\u2082 succeed), the unknown state |\u03c8\u3009 in mode 0 is faithfully transferred to mode 4 at Node C.\n\nPhoton storage is implemented passively by encoding connectivity constraints: the two pair sources emit asynchronously and we forbid any direct source\u2192detector paths that would mix modes 1\u21c42 (for M\u2081) or 1\u2032\u21c43 (for M\u2082) before the other photon arrives. Practically, in the Pytheus config we use \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to block paths from a given source to certain detectors, enforcing that photons must traverse the APT module and effectively \u201cwait\u201d for their partners.\n\nWhy this is interesting:\n  \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric Bell\u2010measurements are a new primitive in linear\u2010optics networks\u2014non\u2010Hermitian symmetry in the measurement module could yield unexpected interference or loss\u2010robustness features.  \n  \u2022 Cascaded teleportation demonstrates a minimal repeater architecture within a single static linear\u2010optical network, illustrating network\u2010level functionality beyond state generation.  \n  \u2022 The passive\u2010storage abstraction via connectivity constraints is a general trick: it can be scaled to longer repeater chains or multiple hops.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus parameters (sketch):\n  num_pre: 1  \n  edges_tried: 50  \n  num_anc: 4  (two ancillas per Bell module)  \n  single_emitters: []  \n  removed_connections: [\n    # block direct creation of both photons in M\u2081 by same source\n    [source1, detector_for_mode0], [source1, detector_for_mode2], \n    # block direct creation for M\u2082 similarly\n    [source2, detector_for_mode1\u2032], [source2, detector_for_mode3]\n  ]  \n  heralding_out: [[d1,e1],[d2,e2]]  \n  target_mapping: input modes [0,1,3] \u2192 output mode [4], conditional on heralding, reproducing the input qubit.\n\nThis proposal is ready for Pytheus to optimize the two APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules and demonstrate networked teleportation with built-in passive storage.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal\u2019s APT\u2010symmetric Bell modules are essentially the same non\u2010Hermitian/ PT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers already suggested, and chaining two teleportations is a standard repeater trick. Nodes A, B, C each hold an unknown qubit in modes 0,1,2 respectively. Three independent probabilistic pair\u2010sources pre\u2010share Bell pairs around the triangle:\n \u2022 S_AB emits into modes [3\u2192B] & [4\u2192A]  \n \u2022 S_BC emits into modes [5\u2192C] & [6\u2192B]  \n \u2022 S_CA emits into modes [7\u2192A] & [8\u2192C]  \n\nWe perform three Bell\u2010measurements (all implemented by four\u2010port APT\u2010symmetric linear\u2010optical analyzers):\n 1. At A: measure modes [2 (C\u2019s input) & 7 (from S_CA)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_C to mode 4 (A\u2019s output).  \n 2. At C: measure [1 (B\u2019s input) & 5 (from S_BC)] \u2192 teleports \u03c8_B to mode 8 (C\u2019s output).  \n\nEach Bell module uses two ancilla photons and two heralding detectors. Passive \u201cphoton storage\u201d is enforced by removed_connections that forbid any pair\u2010source from sending both of its photons directly to a given Bell\u2010detector pair\u2014ensuring one photon must wait for its partner to traverse the APT module. Only upon triple heralding do modes [4,6,8] contain the cyclicly permuted qubits (\u03c8_C,\u03c8_A,\u03c8_B).\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 It realizes a measurement\u2010induced three\u2010party cyclic SWAP\u2014an elementary network primitive beyond single\u2010link teleportation or swapping.  \n \u2022 APT\u2010symmetric modules could exhibit directional success\u2010probability bias or loss tolerance, revealing new non\u2010Hermitian network effects.  \n \u2022 The passive\u2010storage\u2010via\u2010connectivity trick is general and scales to longer loops or higher\u2010party permutation networks.\n\nSketch of Pytheus config:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Three\u2010party cyclic teleportation with APT\u2010symmetric Bell analyzers and passive storage\",\n  \"foldername\": \"cyclic_TP_APT\",\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"edges_tried\": 50,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 6,                    #
